paper_title.en: Magnetic dead layers induced by strain at fct Fe/Rh(001) interface

description.en: We have studied magnetic properties of face-centered-tetragonal (fct) Fe thin films grown at room temperature on the Rh(001) surface. Band structure calculations show that the stable magnetic phase of fct Fe on the Rh(001) surface is ferromagnetic (FM), which agrees with our previous conclusion obtained by angle-resolved photoelectron spectroscopy and spin- and angle-resolved photoelectron spectroscopy (SARPES) of the four monolayers (ML) Fe film [K. Hayashi et al.: Phys. Rev. B 64 (2001) 054417]. This magnetic phase of fct Fe is also confirmed by the SARPES spectra of 3 ML Fe/Rh(001). On the other hand the thickness dependence of the Curie temperature estimated by SARPES and of local magnetic moment by soft X-ray magnetic circular dichroism, experiments show that the Fe films below 2 ML are not FM, i.e., they are magnetic dead layers. We conclude that these magnetic dead layers are caused by a large strain at the Fe/Rh(001) interface.

publication_name.en: JOURNAL OF THE PHYSICAL SOCIETY OF JAPAN

paper_title.en: Perpendicular magnetic anisotropy of Co/Pd(111) studied by spin-resolved photoelectron spectroscopy

description.en: We have studied electronic and magnetic properties of Co/Pd(111) by means of spin- and angle-resolved photoelectron spectroscopy. The perpendicular magnetic anisotropy (PMA) was observed in Co films below 3.5 ML, above which the magnetization direction changes from perpendicular to parallel to the surface. It was found that a simple model calculation based on magnetocrystalline anisotropy qualitatively well explains the emergence of the PMA in Co/Pd(111), where the strong hybridisation between Co 3d and Pd 4d states at the interface plays a crucial role. The re-orientation of the magnetization direction observed in Co films over 3.5 ML is due to the result of the increase of Co 3d electrons with orbital moment parallel to the surface as the Co film thickness increases.

publication_name.en: JOURNAL OF THE PHYSICAL SOCIETY OF JAPAN

Electronic Structures of CeNi<sub>2</sub>Al<sub>5</sub> and CeNiAl<sub>4</sub> studied by photoelectron spectroscopy
Spin-dependent occupied surface state of Fe(001)

description.en: We have observed experimental energy band dispersions of the surface electronic states of Fe(001) by spin- and angle-resolved photoemission spectroscopy. We have shown that the majority spin surface state exists below the Fermi level throughout the <(Gamma)over bar> - <(Delta)over bar> - (X) over bar symmetry line in the surface Brillouin zone and there is mo evidence of the minority spin surface states predicted by a theoretical calculation. Comparing the experimental results with the calculations, we suggest that the enhancement of the surface magnetic moment is larger than predicted. (C) 1998 Published by Elsevier Science Ltd.

paper_title.en: Spin-resoved photoemission of ferromagnetic Ni valence band (invited)

Spin-integrated and spin-resolved photoemission study of Fe chalcogenides
Electron correlation effects in ferromagnetic Ni observed by spin- and angle-resolved photoemission

description.en: We have measured spin- and angle-resolved photoemission spectra of ferromagnetic Ni(110) and obtained the energy band structure along the whole Gamma-K-X direction in the Brillouin zone. Comparing the experimentally observed band structure with theoretical calculations, we confirmed that the electron correlation effect appears more obviously in the majority spin states of the valence band spectra than in the minority spin spectra. We also observed that the exchange splitting shows a momentum dependence in the Brillouin zone according to the different contribution of t(2g) and e(g) states to Ni 3d bands. (C) 1998 Elsevier Science Ltd. All rights reserved.

Line shape asymmetry of 2p core level photoemission spectrum of Al(001) single crystal

description.en: The Al 2p photoemission spectrum has been measured at low temperature (35K) with a resolution of 112 meV using synchrotron radiation. From the observed spectrum, the surface component lines were clearly resolved from the bulk. The spectral line shape has been analyzed by a least-squares-fitting method, and the precise values of the singularity index, the lifetime width and the spin-orbit splitting were obtained. We found that the singularity index is 0.058 +/- 0.002 and is considerably smaller than those reported previously.

publication_name.en: JOURNAL OF THE PHYSICAL SOCIETY OF JAPAN
